hey there it's naz and welcome to an

what makes it incredible well the films
we are discussing of course but more
specifically the writers behind these
films yes everyone remembers the tom
cruises and most people remember the

the writers are the unsung heroes the
true visionaries i mean after all a film
is only as good as its script here's a
little test can you name the
screenwriters that penned your top five
favorite films it's not easy is it and
here's an even more revealing question
of those five screenwriters how many are
women according to an article in variety
women make up only 17 of all working
screenwriters in 2021 and before emerald
finnell script won in 2021 for promising
young woman a woman hadn't taken home
the best original screenplay oscar since
diablo cody who won for juno back in
2007 which honestly feels like ages ago
i mean it kinda was women have been
underrepresented in hollywood since the
beginning especially when it comes to
screenwriting but one thing is for sure
there is no shortage of female-driven
brilliance at our viewing disposal so
without further ado i present to you our
selections for incredible movies written
by women
metropolis
starting with the 1927 silent classic
metropolis written by theovon harbour
and based on her novel of the same name
published two years prior the film is
set in the future and presents a
beautiful utopian society existing above
a bleak underworld populated by
mistreated workers one youthful member
of the privileged class named freder
discovers the grim scene under the city
and enlists the help of a rebellious
teacher named maria to unite the workers
and overcome the expansive class divide
however this proves to be difficult
because freder's authoritative father
happens to be the utopian city's master
and doesn't exactly align with his son's
vision metropolis featured
groundbreaking special effects and set
designs with the cityscape inspired by
director fritz lang's first visit to new
york in the 1920s
lang is also considered a pioneer of the
science fiction genre and though
metropolis isn't technically the first
sci-fi film it's certainly one of the
most innovative and one of the earliest
displays of that genre's limitless
potential in cinema but let's not forget
the true visionary behind metropolis
harbour who was also lang's creative
partner and wife at the time harvoo had
already established herself as a
prolific writer in germany publishing
her first novel in 1910 at the age of
only 22. she would go on to receive
universal recognition for her novels and
additionally for her contributions to
film not only writing several other
successful movies with lang but also
pending scripts for directors fw morneau
carl dreyer and e.a dupont in time
metropolis has received critical praise
with roger ebert calling it one of the
great achievements of the silent era a
work so audacious in its vision and so
angry in its message that it is if
anything more powerful today than when
it was made and honestly we couldn't
agree more
halloween
[Music]
this next feature births one of the most
feared and mythologized antagonists ever
michael myers and no we're not talking
about the guy in austin powers we are
talking about the villain in halloween
written by deborah hill this indie
slasher was released in 1978 and
directed by none other than john
carpenter who also co-wrote the script
with hill the movie follows our favorite
masked maniac as he escapes the
sanitarium and returns to his hometown
of haddonfield illinois where he sucks a
young babysitter named laurie strode
played by jamie lee curtis hill's career
in the biz began in 1975 where she
worked as a production assistant on
documentaries she quickly worked her way
up to the job of scripps supervisor
where she first met carpenter assisting
on his 1976 film assault on precinct 13.
only a couple years later hill and
carpenter would co-write halloween a
movie made on a shoestring budget of
just over 300 000 that went on to gross
over 70 million
[Music]
[Applause]
hill's creative journey was nothing
short of meteoric and her professional
relationship with carpenter would last
decades spawning two halloween sequels
and the films the fog escape from new
york and escape from la the script for
halloween took 10 days to write with
hill crafting most of the females
characters dialogues using her
experience working as a babysitter
during her teenage years as inspiration
though the film received mixed reviews
upon release it has since been
recognized as one of the greatest and
most influential horror films ever made
and has been selected for preservation
in the us national film registry by the
library of congress by the way there are
now a total of 12 halloween films in the
franchise but it's pretty hard to top
the hill carpenter duo that brought us
the first three

of the coppola's lost in translation was
written and directed by sophia the
youngest child and only daughter of
filmmakers eleanor and francis ford
coppola sophia is as close to royalty as
you can get in hollywood but that
doesn't mean she didn't tirelessly work
to carve her own path and craft a
powerful and original voice in 1999
while still in her 20s coppola premiered
her featured directorial debut the
virgin suicides which received critical
praise and cemented her as a filmmaking
force to be reckoned with just over four
years later she released lost in
translation and this is where things got
crazy this movie became a phenomenon
grossing over 118 million against a
budget of just 4 million it's the story
of an aging movie star named bob harris
played by bill murray who chance meets a
conflicted newlywed named charlotte in
tokyo bob is there shooting a japanese
whiskey commercial and charlotte is
there to accompany her celebrity
photographer husband the two connect to
strangers in a foreign land and soon
they form an unlikely but heartfelt bond
as they explore the city and find solace
in each other's company does it get
easier

coppola described the film as a story
about quote things being disconnected
and looking for moments of connection
and she based the plot and themes on her
own experiences traveling to tokyo in
her early 20s the writer director was
set on casting murray for the lead and
infamously pursued him for months
sending letters and leaving countless
voicemails he finally accepted and soon
coppola cast scarlett johansson as
co-star charlotte after liking her
performance in manny and lo murray and
johansson made for an odd but somehow
magnetic on-screen duo and their
chemistry was instrumental to the film's
success critics unanimously praised lost
in translation with newsweek pointing
out that quote with this film it becomes
clear that sofia coppola is a filmmaker
with eyes all her own coppola also took
home the oscar for best original

the writer is a modern western written
and directed by chloe zhao and released
in april of 2018. the film centers
around the lakota sioux tribe of the
pine ridge reservation in south dakota
and specifically follows a young cowboy
named brady who suffers brain damage
from a rodeo accident brady's injury is
left him with a metal plate in his head
and his doctors have ordered him to
never return to the saddle because any
further damage would likely be fatal as
brady digests this news and his altered
way of life he finds himself wandering
the reservation struggling to find a new
purpose xiao rose to prominence in 2015
with the success of her first feature
film songs my brother taught me which
earned her nominations for best verse
feature and the someone to watch award
at the independent spirit awards
i know you're turning away from your
buddies and i know you don't want to do
that

zhao also set songs my brothers taught
me at the pine ridge reservation and her
time there helped to inspire the
screenplay and somewhat true story that
would eventually become the writer in
fact part of what gave the writer an
unparalleled authenticity was zhao's
decision to cast real people playing
themselves the protagonist brady is
inspired by and played by brady and the
same goes for brady's family this was a
bold choice on xiao's part and
unprecedented in cinema the writer was a
small commercial success but received
universal acclaim with many highlighting
zhao's direction and the raw
performances from the untrained cast the
chicago reader called it an
extraordinary translation of life into
art and sight and sound wrote that it
reshapes the traditional cowboy
narrative in a way that both embraces
and challenges western tropes in 2021
zhao won the best picture and best
director oscars for her film nomad land
making her the first asian woman and
only the second woman ever to win best
director at the oscars some
well-deserved history making right there

wang stated that she had been driven by
how conflicted she was between the value

last but not least is portrait of a lady
on fire a french romance drama written
and directed by celine shiyama the film
stars noemi milan and adele now and is
set in france at the end of the 18th
century it's a story of an artist named
marianne who is commissioned by a
powerful family to paint a wedding
portrait for their daughter eloise
as the painting commences marianne and
eloise develop a mutual attraction and a
passionate love affair ensues chiama's
work is known for its themes of gender
fluidity and sexual identity and the
brilliant director writer has been
crafting her singular voice since the
release of her first feature water
lilies back in 2007
for a portrait of a lady on fire shiyama
chose this particular moment in art
history because she wanted to draw
attention to the hundreds of women
painters at the time who had flourishing
careers and have been largely left out
of the narrative film critic rachel
seamy of the new yorker poignantly wrote
that the film examines quote the
entanglements between artistic creation
and burgeoning love between memory and
ambition and freedom the film is about
the erotic electric connection between
women when they find their desire for
creative experience fulfilled in each
other but it is equally about the powers
of art to validate preserve and console
after a romance is over i mean that's
powerful that was really deep and that's
a perfect place to wrap up our list of
